citing_paper_authors: Marilyn A., Walker | Owen, Rambow | Monica, Rogati
raw_text: Human-humandialogs, however, may not provide a very good model of sentence planning strategies for a computational system because the sentence planner must plan communicative goals such as implicit confirmation which are needed to prevent and correct errors in automatic speech recognition but which are rare in human-human dialog. Other related work deals with discourse-related aspects of sentence planning such as cue word placement (Moser and Moore, 1995), clearly a crucial task whose integration into our approach we leave to future work. Mellish et al (1998) investigate the problem of deter mining a discourse tree for a set of elementary speech acts which are partially constrained by rhetorical relations
clean_text: Mellish et al (1998) investigate the problem of determining a discourse tree for a set of elementary speech acts which are partially constrained by rhetorical relations.

raw_text: Mellish et al (1998) (and subsequently Karamanis and Manurung 2002) advocate genetic algorithms asan alternative to exhaustively searching for the optimal ordering of descriptions of museum arte facts
clean_text: Mellish et al (1998) (and subsequently Karamanis and Manurung 2002) advocate genetic algorithms as an alternative to exhaustively searching for the optimal ordering of descriptions of museum artefacts.

raw_text: Following previous work (Mellish et al, 1998) we used a single fitness function that scored candidates based on their coherence
clean_text: Following previous work (Mellish et al, 1998) we used a single fitness function that scored candidates based on their coherence.

raw_text: The genetic algorithms ofMellish et al (1998) and Karamanis and Manarung (2002), as well as the greedy algorithm of Lapata (2003), provide no theoretical guarantees on the optimality of the solutions they propose. At the other end of the spectrum, the exhaustive search of Barzilay and Lee (2004), while ensuring optimal solutions, is prohibitively expensive, and can not be used to perform utility-based training
clean_text: The genetic algorithms of Mellish et al (1998) and Karamanis and Manarung (2002), as well as the greedy algorithm of Lapata (2003), provide no theoretical guarantees on the optimality of the solutions they propose.

raw_text: Mellish et al (1998) advocate stochastic search as an alternative to exhaustively examining the search space
clean_text: Mellish et al (1998) advocate stochastic search as an alternative to exhaustively examining the search space.

raw_text: Asinthe case of Mellish et al (1998) we construct an acceptable ordering rather than the best possible one

raw_text: Mellish et al (1998) made the point that even this restricted approach would soon become intractable with more than a small set of facts when one allows weak RST relations such as Joint and Elaboration into the model

raw_text: In the late 1990s, Chris Mellish implemented the first stochastic text planner (Mellish et al 1998)
clean_text: In the late 1990s, Chris Mellish implemented the first stochastic text planner (Mellish et al 1998).

raw_text: The evaluation function of Mellish et al (1998) also was calculated over a sum of local features of the tree, although a wider set of features were involved
clean_text: The evaluation function of Mellish et al (1998) also was calculated over a sum of local features of the tree, although a wider set of features were involved.

raw_text: For instance, the evaluation function of Mellish et al (1998) assigned +3 for each instance of subject-repetition
clean_text: For instance, the evaluation function of Mellish et al (1998) assigned +3 for each instance of subject-repetition.

raw_text: Genetic algorithms are also used in [Mellish et al, 1998] where the authors state the problem of given a set of facts to convey and a set of rhetorical relations that can be used to link them together, how one can arrange this material so as to yield the best possible text
